bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ross A. McFarland, March 23, 1948

div1.p: Hench relates his attempts to locate an aerial photograph of Marianao. Hench thanks McFarland for the suggestion to write the American Geographic Society and asks McFarland if he thinks Hench should correspond with the Pan-American office, in New York.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ross A. McFarland, March 23, 1948
div1.opener:
March 23, 1948
Dr. Ross A. McFarland
Harvard University
Division of Research
Soldiers Field
Boston 63, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor McFarland:
div1.p:
Our mutual friend, Jan Tillisch, has referred to me your letter
of March 5. It was extremely kind of both him and you to interest your-
selves in my search for an airplane photograph of the suburb of Havana,
namely, Marianao or Quemados de Marianao. I have just returned from my
Havana. I visited many places there in vain. The Pan-American office
there has several fine airplane photographs of the harbor and the main
part of Havana but none far cast enough to show LaPlaya and the Yacht Club.
The Minister of Public Works did have an aerial map of the section involved,
taken from way up in the air, absolutely perpendicular. This is perhaps
better than nothing but shows things only in two dimensions and does not
give the three dimensional view that laymen need.

When I was in Washington in November, I visited the National
Geographic Society. They had three or four excellent airplane photographs
of downtown Havana which I would like to have borrowed. They were taken
not perpendicularly but tangentially but I was informed that “The National
Geographic Society copyrights all photographs and lends none”.

I am enclosing a little map which shows the section in which I
am so interested. Also, I am enclosing a reprint on the subject. Thank
you for your suggestion that I write the American Geographic Society. I
shall do this.

You mention that you visited the Pan-American office in New York.
Should I correspond with someone there and do you think that they would have
any photographs that the Havana office didn't have.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
